title: Investment Risk Assessment
description: This questionnaire will help us understand your investment goals and risk tolerance to create a personalized portfolio recommendation.

sections.title: Demographics & Time Horizon
sections.description: Understanding your personal situation helps us determine suitable investment strategies.

sections.title: Financial Situation
sections.description: Your current financial position affects how much risk is appropriate for you.

sections.title: Investment Behavior & Reactions
sections.description: How you react to market fluctuations is an important factor in determining your risk profile.

sections.title: Investment Philosophy & Objectives
sections.description: Your personal investment approach and goals guide our recommendations.

sections.title: Hypothetical Scenarios
sections.description: These scenarios help us gauge your risk tolerance in concrete situations.

questions.text: When do you expect to start withdrawing from this investment?

options.text: Less than 3 years
3-5 years
6-10 years
11-20 years

questions.text: How many financial dependents do you have (children, elderly parents, etc.)?

options.text: None
4 or more

questions.text: How would you rate your investment knowledge?

options.text: Very limited - I'm new to investing
Basic - I understand simple investment concepts
Moderate - I understand different investment types
Good - I understand diversification and asset allocation
Advanced - I understand complex investment strategies

questions.text: Which investments have you had experience with? (Select the most advanced)

options.text: Savings accounts and fixed deposits only
Unit trusts and bonds
Stocks and ETFs
Options, futures, or forex
Private equity, hedge funds, or venture capital

questions.text: How stable is your current and future income?

options.text: Very unstable - irregular or uncertain income
Somewhat unstable - some risk to income
Moderate - generally stable but not guaranteed
Stable - secure employment or reliable income sources
Very stable - guaranteed income or multiple secure sources

questions.text: How many months of expenses do you have in emergency savings?

options.text: Less than 1 month
1-3 months
3-6 months
6-12 months
More than 12 months

questions.text: What percentage of your net worth does this investment represent?

options.text: Over 75%
Less than 10%

questions.text: If your investment suddenly lost 20% of its value, what would you do?

options.text: Sell everything immediately
Sell a portion to reduce risk
Do nothing and wait to see what happens
Wait for recovery and then reassess strategy
Buy more at the lower price

questions.text: How would you feel if your investment dropped 15% in a month?

options.text: Extremely uncomfortable - I would have trouble sleeping
Very uncomfortable - I would worry a lot
Moderately uncomfortable but manageable
Slightly uncomfortable but not worried
Comfortable - I understand downturns are part of investing

questions.text: Which of these statements best describes your current investment approach?

options.text: I keep all my money in savings accounts, fixed deposits, or government bonds
I invest mostly in conservative instruments with a small portion in blue-chip stocks
I have a balanced mix of stocks and bonds in my portfolio
I invest primarily in stocks with some allocation to more speculative investments
I actively seek high-risk, high-reward investments including emerging markets, small caps, or cryptocurrencies

questions.text: Which statement best describes your investment philosophy?

options.text: I cannot tolerate any investment losses
I can tolerate small losses occasionally
I can accept moderate losses if the long-term outlook is positive
I can accept significant short-term losses for long-term growth
I focus on maximum long-term returns regardless of short-term losses

questions.text: What is your primary investment objective?

options.text: Preserve capital - avoid loss at all costs
Income generation - steady income with minimal growth
Balanced - moderate growth with some income
Growth - focus on long-term capital appreciation
Aggressive growth - maximize returns at all costs

questions.text: How important is liquidity in this investment?

options.text: Very important - I may need immediate access to all funds
Important - I may need access to most funds within a year
Somewhat important - I may need partial access occasionally
Less important - I likely won't need access for several years
Not important - This is purely long-term money

questions.text: Imagine you have $10,000 to invest for 5 years. Which option would you choose?

options.text: Guaranteed return of $1,500 (total: $11,500) with no possibility of loss
90% chance of gaining $3,000 (total: $13,000), but 10% chance of losing $500 (total: $9,500)
80% chance of gaining $5,000 (total: $15,000), but 20% chance of losing $1,000 (total: $9,000)
70% chance of gaining $7,500 (total: $17,500), but 30% chance of losing $2,000 (total: $8,000)
60% chance of gaining $10,000 (total: $20,000), but 40% chance of losing $3,000 (total: $7,000)

questions.text: The table below shows five hypothetical portfolios. Which would you choose?

options.text: Portfolio A: 4% Expected Return, -5% Worst Case, 13% Best Case
Portfolio B: 6% Expected Return, -10% Worst Case, 20% Best Case
Portfolio C: 8% Expected Return, -15% Worst Case, 28% Best Case
Portfolio D: 10% Expected Return, -25% Worst Case, 35% Best Case
